qas.question: Large amounts of sulfur dioxide and cadmium vapor are produced due to what?

answers.text: The production for sulfidic zinc ores

qas.question: Smelter slag contains a significant amount of what?
Why does the Geul River contain heavy metals in a significant amount?

answers.text: mining operations leach significant amounts of zinc and cadmium

qas.question: What is the ratio that anthropogenic and natural emissions occur at?

plausible_answers.text: The production for sulfidic zinc ores

qas.question: What produces tiny amounts of sulfur dioxide and cadmium vapor?
What does smelter slag contain a trivial amount of?

plausible_answers.text: mining operations leach significant amounts of zinc and cadmium

qas.question: Why does the Geul River contain no heavy metals?
What is the ratio that anthropogenic and unnatural emissions occur at?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>The production for sulfidic zinc ores<b4_0/><a0_0/> produces large amounts of sulfur dioxide and cadmium vapor. Smelter slag and other residues of process also contain significant amounts of <a1_0><b5_0>heavy metals<b5_0/><a1_0/>. About 1.1 million tonnes of metallic zinc and 130 thousand tonnes of lead were mined and smelted in the Belgian towns of La Calamine and Plombières between 1806 and 1882. The dumps of the past <a2_0><b6_0>mining operations leach significant amounts of zinc and cadmium<b6_0/><a2_0/>, and, as a result, the sediments of the Geul River contain significant amounts of heavy metals. About two thousand years ago emissions of zinc from mining and smelting totaled 10 thousand tonnes a year. After increasing 10-fold from 1850, zinc emissions peaked at 3.4 million tonnes per year in the 1980s and declined to 2.7 million tonnes in the 1990s, although a 2005 study of the Arctic troposphere found that the concentrations there did not reflect the decline. Anthropogenic and natural emissions occur at a ratio of <a3_0><b7_0>20 to 1<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
